Award.AwardTitle: Development of Experience-Dependent Responses to Voice Pitch in Newborns and Infants

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intonation as a change in voice pitch can carry important information in communication. In non-tonal languages such as American English, differences in intonation can change a statement into a question while in tonal languages such as Mandarin Chinese, intonations can change the meaning of every single spoken word. Despite its apparent importance, it remains unclear whether and how the ability to perceive tonal difference is acquired through learning during early development. To address this important question, Dr. Fuh-Cherng Jeng of University of Ohio proposes a project to be conducted at two infant centers, one in the United State and one in Taiwan, to first investigate whether newborn babies born to a tonal (Taiwan) and atonal (US) language environments differ in their ability to perceive intonation and to then follow up 3 months later to assess whether the exposure to different language environment lead to changes in this ability. Dr. Jeng will employ non-invasive electrophysiological techniques to measure how brain activity in subcortical and cortical structures changes in response to voice pitch at each point of the development. Through this technically challenging study, Dr. Jeng expects to answer the question whether the ability to detect intonation is learned or innate and how plastic are the infant brains in response to exposure to early life language environment.

The proposed study could lead to new approaches for diagnosis and possible remediation of developmental disorders of language. In particular, this research may have implications for the early detection and identification of social/communicative disorders such as autism. Furthermore, through the US-Taiwan collaboration, the PI creates exceptional opportunities for US graduate students with extensive international experience. These experiences are expected to broaden their understanding of research in a different cultural context, help students develop personal relations with Chinese researchers, and lay the foundation for initiating their own future international collaboration activity. Such experiences will also provide teaching and training opportunities for the students to deal with challenges and benefits of conducting research on a global stage. Finally, Dr. Jeng will participate in the big data effort by making the data available to support other coordinated NSF efforts that aim to make use of real data in the teaching of STEM related courses and to enable participation in discovery science by those who would otherwise have no access to such data.

This project is co-funded by the International Science and Engineering Section of the NSF Office of International and Integrative Activities

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview 

The purpose of this study was to determine the relative contributions of innate factors and language exposure on the brain’s ability to track changes in voice pitch by examining newborns (1-3 days old) and young infants (3 months old) from two distinct linguistic environments—American English and Mandarin Chinese. Using objective and non-invasive techniques that were capable of measuring the brain’s processing of voice pitch, a total of 60 American and 60 Chinese newborn participants were recruited. Follow-ups of these newborns were scheduled at 3 months of age.

 

Intellectual Merit of the Proposed Activity 

Results of this study were fruitful because a few gaps in our knowledge that were unknown before are now filled with positive findings. Specifically, this study first demonstrated the feasibility of assessing the brain’s processing of voice pitch during immediate postnatal days. Our ability to evaluate the brain’s responses to speech stimuli that differed only in pitch contours were further confirmed by the high-quality data collected in both the American and Chinese newborns who were 1-3 days old. Furthermore, results of this study demonstrated comparable responses obtained from the American and Chinese newborns. This finding supported the idea that infants were born universally with necessary anatomical structures and functional capacities to track pitch contours, which provided a basis for language acquisition. Additionally, our results demonstrated that the rising and dipping pitch contours elicited responses with better accuracy and larger amplitudes than the other pitch contours. This finding supported the theory of differential pitch representation in newborns during their immediate postnatal days. Upon follow-ups of these newborn participants, the brain’s processing to voice pitch was further investigated when the infants were 3 months of age. Processing and tracking of voice pitch showed significant improvement by the time the infants were 3 months of age. This finding filled the much-needed gap in our understanding of the developmental trajectory of pitch processing during the early stages of life.

 

Broader Impacts Resulting from the Proposed Activity 

By using a cross-language study design and follow-ups of infants’ responses to voice pitch after birth, this innovative approach produced exciting outcomes with positive impacts. For example, the optimal acoustic features in terms of the various voice pitch contours were identified to elicit the strongest responses in newborns and infants. Data collected in the study not only have provided answers to existing gaps in knowledge but also have boosted our knowledge about the acquisition of voice pitch perception in normal populations and have laid a foundation for pathological populations. Such results have important positive impacts, because it is expected that the identified components will enable better detection of pitch perception problems at a very early stage in development, and potentially will provide new directions for preventive and therapeutic interventions. Benefits of this new knowledge will also accrue to both basic and clinical researchers interested in language development and brain plasticity. Longer-term public health implications of this line of research include the potential to detect auditory perceptual deficits in newborns or infants, deeming them at risk for delays in auditory perception or language acquisition, and the potential to intervene early in infants’ development to prevent or remediate future auditory learning and communication disorders.
